2 dice, X=1st observed number, Y=2nd observed number
|S|=6 choices for X * 6 choices for Y=36
roll fair die until # > 4 is observed, N=# of rolls, P(N=k), k=1,2,3,...
20 questions, each has 4 options. Know answer to 10 qestions, X=# correct answer.
P(X=11)=P(getting 9 questions wrong)=P(#1R,others wrong)+P(#2R,others wrong)+...P(#10R, others wrong)
X=pascal(m, p), Y=pascal(l, p), Z=X+Y, find PMF(Z)
pascal=flip coin until m heads is observed
P(m-1 H in k-1 flip)=P(observed m-1 H in k-1 flip)=binomial(k-1, p)
# ways to pick m-1 success slots in k-1 slots, no replacement:
note that all m-1 success are indistiguishable from each other, so order doesnt matter.
there are (m-1)! permutations of m-1 success slot that are double counted, so # of ways to choose m-1 success slots in k-1 slots is
X=# flips until m H is observed, Y=# flips until l H is observed
Z=# flips until m+l H is observed? so PMF=pascal(m+l, p)?
X partitions Z, so use total probability
seems to be true, but i dont know how to write a combinatoric proof for this
X=poisson(a), Y=poisson(b), X, Y independent, Z=X+Y
note that X partitions Z, every X is part of every Z
check if PMF(Y) is a proper probability distribution, should sum up to 1
